prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Imaging:
We will make 7-point mosaics to cover the high-mass clumps in both IRDCs, using configuration C34-2 at 225 GHz. At this configuration and frequency, we will have an angular resolution of ~1.0" (~5,000 AU or ~0.02 pc) and the maximum recoverable scale will be 11". This angular resolution is desirable to well resolve the Jeans length (~20,000 AU) and be able to spatially separate the cores. Because we want to estimate the core masses at small scales, filtering out emission at large scales (>11") will reduce the contribution of material from the surrounding clump. Thus, ACA is not required for this project.
Given the mass sensitivity, we need dynamic ranges of 50 and 400 to detect the full spectrum in mass from the 5$\sigma$ value (0.2 Msun) to the maximum mass as detected by SMA. If the SMA cores fragment at higher resolution, the dynamic range needed is smaller. Basic calibration results in the VLA produce dynamic ranges of the order of 1000, using 27 antennas (Thompson et al. 2007). ALMA Cycle 2 with 34 antennas should be able to do similarly, or even better.
Correlator setup:
All spectral windows in three basebands will be used with a bandwidth of 117 MHz (150 km/s) and a spectral resolution of 244 kHz (0.3 km/s). The remaining baseband will be used with a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz and a spectral resolution of 976 kHz (1.3 km/s).
A spectral resolution of 0.3 km/s is needed to resolve linewidths of 1.5 km/s, which are expected in emission from deuterated molecules (e.g.,Sanhueza et al. 2013). A good determination of linewidths is required to reduce uncertainties in Gaussian fittings and determine more accurate virial parameters. We will observe N2D+ 3-2, DNC 3-2, DCN 3-2, DCO+ 3-2, and 13CS 5-4.
To reduce the data rate to less than 12 MB/s, we average channels in the spectral windows where we could detect CO, SiO, and CH3OH. These three molecules trace high-velocity gas and they will not be affected by using 0.6 km/s. Two spectral windows with bandwidth of 117 MHz and the baseband of 1.875 GHz will be used for continuum emission.
The total aggregate bandwidth is 3.3 GHz.
Sensitivity:
we request sufficient continuum sensitivity to detect cores below the turnover mass at ~0.5 Msun and an adequate spectral resolution to detect and resolve spectral lines of at least 800 mK and line widths ~1.5 km/s.
We request a continuum sensitivity of 0.032 mJy to reach a mass sensitivity of 0.2 Msun (5$\sigma$). This value is obtained by assuming a dust opacity of 1.0 cm^2 g^-1, a gas-to-dust mass ratio of 100:1, a dust temperature of 13 K, and a distance of 5.5 kpc. This mass is low enough to cover the turnover mass of ~0.5 Msun. Using the Observing Tool and the aggregate bandwidth of 3.3 GHz, we obtain the continuum sensitivity of 0.032 mJy in 3 hrs (including overheads).
The weakest line expected in our setup is N_2D^+ 3-2. To estimate the brightness of this line we look at the recent work of Tan et al. (2013). They observed with ALMA at 2.3" angular resolution 4 prestellar clumps of lower masses (~100 Msun) and similar temperatures (10 K) compared with our sample. They obtain an average brightness for N_2D^+ of ~400 mK. Due to the larger masses in our clumps, the peak H_2 column densities in the cores we resolve with SMA are at least a factor 2 larger than those that Tan et al. obtain in the cores resolved by ALMA. Assuming our cores and their cores represent a similar evolutionary stage, we may expect a similar abundance of N_2D^+. Thus, we expect N_2D^+ 3-2 to be at least a factor 2 brighter than in Tan et al. sources, i.e., 800 mK. We request a S/N of at least 10, to obtain a good. Using a spectral resolution of 0.3 km/s and 3 hrs (including overheads), we obtain a line sensitivity of 85 mK, and a S/N of 10 for N_2D^+ 3-2.
In summary, we request 3 hr (including overhead) on each IRDC clump, which is a total time for the proposal of 6 hr.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The two contending models of high-mass star formation, competitive accretion and turbulent core accretion, make different predictions of the core mass function (CMF) and the dynamical state of embedded cores in high-mass cluster-forming clumps. These predictions differ the most at the early evolutionary stages of cluster formation. After several IR, continuum, and molecular line observations, combining space and single dish telescopes, and interferometers, we have identified two prime examples of high-mass cluster-forming clumps (~1500 Msun) in the early, prestellar phase. The competitive accretion model predicts a more sharply peaked CMF centered around the Jeans mass (~0.5 Msun), with cores in a sub-virial state, and the absence of prestellar high-mass cores. In contrast, the turbulent core accretion model predicts that the CMF is closely related to the IMF, with cores close to virial equilibrium, and the existence of prestellar high-mass cores. We propose observation of continuum emission at 1.3 mm to estimate the core's masses and determine the CMF, and observations of deuterated molecules (cold gas tracers) to determine whether or not cores are near virial equilibrium.
